This is useful for testing, debugging, or procedural generation that needs to be repeatable. The seed affects all subsequent random.nextLong() and random.nextDouble() calls until a new seed is set.

parameters.name: seed
parameters.description: Seed value for the random number generator

builtins.example:
// Set seed for reproducible results
call random.setSeed(12345);
var val1 = call random.nextLong(100); // Always 51 with seed 12345
var val2 = call random.nextDouble();

// Reset to same seed
call random.setSeed(12345);
var val3 = call random.nextLong(100); // Also 51
var val4 = call random.nextDouble(); // Same as val2

builtins.long_help: Scales an SVG image by the specified horizontal and vertical scale factors. Values greater than 1.0 enlarge, less than 1.0 shrink.
Sets the width and height of an SVG image. This updates the viewBox dimensions.

builtins.short_description: Sets fill color of SVG elements
builtins.long_help: Sets the fill color of all SVG elements. Color should be specified in hex format (e.g., #ff0000 for red).
Sets the name of the vector image and returns the modified object.

builtins.short_description: Sets stroke color of SVG elements
builtins.long_help: Sets the stroke (outline) color of all SVG elements. Color should be specified in hex format (e.g., #000000 for black).

builtins.short_description: Sets stroke width of SVG elements
builtins.long_help: Sets the stroke (outline) width of all SVG elements.
Returns the SVG data as a byte array.
Alias for vector.toRaster. Converts an SVG vector image to a raster (bitmap) image.
Converts an SVG vector image to a raster (bitmap) image. Optionally specify the target width and height for rasterization.
Returns the SVG data as an XML string.

getting_started.title: Getting Started with EBS
getting_started.content:
Welcome to EBS (Earl Bosch Script)! 1. Write your first script: 
   var message: string = "Hello, World!";
   print message;
2. Run it in the console or save as .ebs file • Variables with type annotations or inference • Control flow (if/then/else, while, for, foreach) • Functions with parameters and return values • Arrays (fixed and dynamic) and JSON objects • Database operations (connect, cursor, SQL) • File I/O and HTTP requests • JavaFX screen/UI support • Rich set of 200+ built-in functions • Explore 'Program Structure' for syntax basics • Check 'Data Types' for available types • Browse 'Built-in Functions' by category • View 'Examples' for practical code samples

builtin_cat_overview.title: {category_name}

Syntax.title: EBS (Earl Bosch Script) Syntax
Syntax.content:
EBS is a dynamically-typed scripting language with:
• Familiar C-like syntax
• Native JSON support
• Integrated database capabilities
• JavaFX-based UI screen support
• Rich set of built-in functions
• Interactive REPL environment
Select a topic from the tree to view detailed information.

structure.title: Program Structure
structure.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ Program Structure Overview ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ EBS programs are built from several key structural elements: ▸ BASIC SYNTAX ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────── • Statements end with semicolons (;) • Comments use double-slash (//) • Code blocks use curly braces { } • Case-sensitive language (myVar ≠ MyVar) ▸ VARIABLES ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────── • Declare with 'var' keyword • Optional type annotations (var x: int) • Type inference when type not specified • Constants with 'const' keyword • Support for primitive and complex types ▸ OPERATORS ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────── • Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, % • Comparison: ==, !=, <, >, <=, >= • Logical: and, or, not • Assignment: = • String concatenation: + ▸ FUNCTIONS ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────── • Named functions with parameters • Optional return types • Support for default parameter values • Local variable scoping • Recursive function calls supported ▸ IMPORTS ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────── • Import other EBS files • Access functions and variables from imported files • Relative path imports • Prevents circular dependencies EXAMPLE - Complete Program Structure: 
// Comments explain the code
import "utilities.ebs";

// Global variables
var appName: string = "MyApp";
const VERSION: string = "1.0.0";

// Function definition
greet(name: string) return string {
    var message: string = "Hello, " + name + "!";
    return message;
}

// Main program logic
var userName: string = "Alice";
var greeting: string = call greet(userName);
print greeting;

if userName.length > 0 then {
    print "Welcome to " + appName + " v" + VERSION;
}
Select a sub-topic from the tree for detailed information: ▸ Basic - Statements, comments, blocks, case handling ▸ Variables - Variable declarations, types, constants ▸ Operators - Arithmetic, comparison, logical operators ▸ Functions - Function definitions and calls ▸ Imports - Code organization with imports

EBS provides several primitive data types for storing values.
Select a data type from the tree to view detailed information:
▸ Integer Types - int, long, byte
▸ Floating Point - float, double
▸ String - Text data
▸ Boolean - true/false values
▸ Date - Date and time values

flow.content:
Select a sub-topic from the tree to view detailed information:
▸ Conditionals - if-then-else statements
▸ Loops - while, for, foreach, do-while
▸ Break and Continue - Loop control
▸ Exceptions - Error handling

keywords.title: EBS Language Keywords
keywords.content:
This table lists all reserved keywords in the EBS scripting language.
Keyword Type Description
var Variable Declaration Declares a variable
print Output Outputs text to the console
call Function Invokes a builtin function
return Function Returns a value from a block
if Control Flow Conditional statement
then Control Flow Follows an if condition
else Control Flow Alternative branch in conditional
foreach Control Flow Iterates over a collection
in Control Flow Part of foreach loop syntax
while Control Flow Conditional loop
do Control Flow Introduces loop body
break Control Flow Exits a loop
continue Control Flow Skips to next loop iteration
connect Database Establishes database connection
use Database Executes code with a connection
cursor Database Declares a database cursor
open Database Opens a database cursor
close Database Closes a cursor or connection
connection Database References a database connection
select SQL SQL SELECT statement
from SQL Specifies table in SQL query
where SQL Filters SQL query results
order SQL Sorts SQL query results
by SQL Specifies ordering column
group SQL Groups SQL query results
having SQL Filters grouped results
screen UI Creates a UI window
null Literals Represents absence of value
true Literals Boolean true value
false Literals Boolean false value
bitmap Type Definitions Defines named bit fields within a byte
intmap Type Definitions Defines named bit fields within an integer
array.bitmap Type Definitions Creates a bitmap array backed by ArrayFixedByte
array.intmap Type Definitions Creates an intmap array backed by ArrayFixedInt
record Type Definitions Defines structured data with named, typed fields

builtins.title: call string.toUpper(text)
builtins.content:
STRING FUNCTIONS: 
  call string.toUpper(text)
  call string.toLower(text)
  call string.trim(text)
  call string.substring(text, start, end)
  call string.indexOf(text, search)
  call string.length(text)
ARRAY FUNCTIONS: 
  arr.length        // Get array length (property access)
  call array.add(arr, value)   // Add element
  call array.remove(arr, idx)  // Remove element
  call array.sort(arr)         // Sort array
MATH FUNCTIONS: 
  call math.abs(num)
  call math.max(a, b)
  call math.min(a, b)
  call math.round(num)
  call math.sqrt(num)
FILE I/O: 
  call file.readTextFile(path)
  call file.writeTextFile(path, content)
  call file.exists(path)

screen.title: Screens
screen.content:
Screens create JavaFX UI windows (Stages) with interactive components. Select a sub-topic from the tree to view detailed information: ▸ screen_data - Screen variables and data binding ▸ screen_display - Display types and component properties ▸ screen_areas - Layout containers and area types ▸ screen_items - Items that bind variables to display components SCREEN OPERATIONS: 
  show screen myWindow;
  hide screen myWindow;
  close screen myWindow;
SCREEN FUNCTIONS: 
  call scr.setValue(screenName, varName, value)
  call scr.getValue(screenName, varName)
  call scr.setProperty(screenName, itemName, property, value)
  call scr.getProperty(screenName, itemName, property)

screen_data.title: Screen Data (vars)

screen_display.title: Screen Display Types
screen_display.content:
OVERVIEW: Display types define how screen variables are shown to users. Each variable can have an optional 'display' object. BASIC STRUCTURE: 
  "vars": [{
      "name": "email",
      "type": "string",
      "display": {
          "type": "textfield",
          "labelText": "Email Address:",
          "labelPosition": "TOP",
          "mandatory": true
      }
  }]
INPUT COMPONENTS: • textfield - Single-line text input • textarea - Multi-line text input • passwordfield - Masked password input • spinner - Numeric value spinner • slider - Value slider control • datepicker - Date selection • colorpicker - Color chooser SELECTION COMPONENTS: • checkbox - Boolean toggle • radiobutton - Single selection from group • togglebutton - Toggle state button • combobox - Dropdown list (editable) • choicebox - Dropdown list (fixed) • listview - Scrollable list • tableview - Tabular data display • treeview - Hierarchical tree view DISPLAY-ONLY COMPONENTS: • label - Static text label • labeltext - Alternative label • text - Text node • hyperlink - Clickable link • separator - Visual divider • image - Image display • webview - HTML/web content • mediaview - Video/audio player • progressbar - Progress indicator (bar) • progressindicator - Progress indicator (circular) INTERACTIVE COMPONENTS: • button - Action button • canvas - Drawing surface • chart - Data visualization COMMON DISPLAY PROPERTIES: • type - Component type (required) • labelText - Label content • labelPosition - TOP, LEFT, RIGHT, BOTTOM, NONE • mandatory - Required field indicator • editable - Enable/disable editing • visible - Show/hide component • tooltip - Hover help text • promptText - Placeholder text • onChange - Event handler code • onClick - Button click handler • onAction - Action event handler EXAMPLE - TEXT INPUT: 
  {
      "name": "description",
      "type": "string",
      "display": {
          "type": "textarea",
          "labelText": "Description:",
          "rows": 5,
          "cols": 40,
          "promptText": "Enter description here..."
      }
  }
EXAMPLE - SELECTION: 
  {
      "name": "country",
      "type": "string",
      "display": {
          "type": "combobox",
          "labelText": "Country:",
          "options": ["USA", "Canada", "UK", "Australia"]
      }
  }
EXAMPLE - BUTTON WITH ACTION: 
  {
      "name": "submitBtn",
      "type": "string",
      "default": "Submit",
      "display": {
          "type": "button",
          "onClick": "call submitForm();"
      }
  }
COMPONENT TYPE ACCESS: 
  print typeof myScreen.email;  // Screen.Textfield
  var field : screen.textfield = myScreen.email;
  print myScreen.email.javafx;  // JavaFX node details

screen_areas.title: Screen Areas (Layout)
screen_areas.content:
OVERVIEW: Areas define layout containers that organize items on screen. The 'area' property contains an array of layout definitions. BASIC STRUCTURE: 
  screen myScreen = {
      "area": [
          {
              "name": "mainArea",
              "type": "vbox",
              "spacing": "10",
              "padding": "10",
              "items": [...]
          }
      ]
  };
CONTAINER TYPES: BASIC CONTAINERS: • pane - Basic positioning container • stackpane - Stacks children on top of each other • anchorpane - Anchors children to edges • region - Base layout region • group - Groups nodes without layout BOX LAYOUTS (Linear): • hbox - Horizontal box (left to right) • vbox - Vertical box (top to bottom) • flowpane - Flow layout (wraps) • tilepane - Tile grid layout ADVANCED LAYOUTS: • gridpane - Grid-based layout • borderpane - Five-region layout (top, bottom, left, right, center) • splitpane - Resizable divider between areas CONTAINERS WITH CHROME: • scrollpane - Adds scrollbars • tabpane - Tabbed interface • tab - Individual tab in tabpane • accordion - Collapsible panels • titledpane - Panel with title bar SPECIAL: • canvas - Drawing area COMMON AREA PROPERTIES: • name - Area identifier • type - Container type (required) • spacing - Space between children • padding - Internal padding • alignment - Child alignment (TOP_LEFT, CENTER, etc.) • hgrow - Horizontal grow priority (ALWAYS, NEVER, SOMETIMES) • vgrow - Vertical grow priority • minWidth, prefWidth, maxWidth - Width constraints • minHeight, prefHeight, maxHeight - Height constraints • style - CSS styling • items - Array of items in this area • areas - Nested areas (for splitpane, borderpane, etc.) EXAMPLE - SIMPLE VBOX: 
  "area": [{
      "name": "formArea",
      "type": "vbox",
      "spacing": "15",
      "padding": "20",
      "alignment": "TOP_LEFT",
      "items": [
          {"name": "nameField", "varRef": "username"},
          {"name": "emailField", "varRef": "email"},
          {"name": "submitBtn", "varRef": "submit"}
      ]
  }]
EXAMPLE - SPLIT PANE: 
  "area": [{
      "name": "splitLayout",
      "type": "splitpane",
      "orientation": "horizontal",
      "dividerPosition": [0.3],
      "areas": [
          {
              "name": "leftPanel",
              "type": "vbox",
              "items": [...]
          },
          {
              "name": "rightPanel",
              "type": "vbox",
              "items": [...]
          }
      ]
  }]
EXAMPLE - GRID PANE: 
  "area": [{
      "name": "gridArea",
      "type": "gridpane",
      "hgap": "10",
      "vgap": "10",
      "items": [
          {"name": "label1", "row": 0, "col": 0, "varRef": "lbl1"},
          {"name": "field1", "row": 0, "col": 1, "varRef": "val1"},
          {"name": "label2", "row": 1, "col": 0, "varRef": "lbl2"},
          {"name": "field2", "row": 1, "col": 1, "varRef": "val2"}
      ]
  }]
EXAMPLE - BORDER PANE: 
  "area": [{
      "name": "borderLayout",
      "type": "borderpane",
      "top": {"name": "header", "type": "hbox", "items": [...]},
      "center": {"name": "content", "type": "vbox", "items": [...]},
      "bottom": {"name": "footer", "type": "hbox", "items": [...]}
  }]
NESTED AREAS: Areas can contain nested areas for complex layouts: 
  "areas": [
      {
          "name": "outer",
          "type": "vbox",
          "areas": [
              {"name": "inner1", "type": "hbox", "items": [...]},
              {"name": "inner2", "type": "hbox", "items": [...]}
          ]
      }
  ]
AREA MANIPULATION: 
  // Get area property
  var visible = call scr.getAreaProperty("myScreen.formArea", "visible");

  // Set area property
  call scr.setAreaProperty("myScreen.formArea", "visible", false);

scr_setproperty_overview.title: scr.setProperty Overview
scr_setproperty_overview.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty - Modify Screen Item Properties ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ OVERVIEW: The scr.setProperty builtin function dynamically modifies properties of screen items at runtime. This allows you to control visibility, appearance, layout, and behavior of UI components. SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, property, value)
PARAMETERS: • areaItem (string) - Format: "screenName.itemName" • property (string) - Property name to set (case-insensitive) • value (any) - New value for the property RETURN VALUE: • Returns true on success PROPERTY CATEGORIES: BEHAVIOR PROPERTIES: • value, text - Control content • editable - Enable/disable editing • disabled - Disable/enable control • visible - Show/hide control APPEARANCE PROPERTIES: • tooltip - Tooltip text • textColor - Text color • backgroundColor - Background color LAYOUT PROPERTIES: • colSpan - Grid column span • rowSpan - Grid row span • hgrow - Horizontal grow priority • vgrow - Vertical grow priority • alignment - Control alignment SPACING PROPERTIES: • margin - External spacing • padding - Internal spacing SIZING PROPERTIES: • prefWidth, prefHeight - Preferred size • minWidth, minHeight - Minimum size • maxWidth, maxHeight - Maximum size EXAMPLES: 
  // Hide a field
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.emailField", "visible", false);
  
  // Disable a button
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.submitBtn", "disabled", true);
  
  // Set text color
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.errorLabel", "textColor", "#FF0000");
  
  // Change size
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.textArea", "prefWidth", "600");
SEE ALSO: • scr.getProperty - Retrieve property values • Select individual properties from tree for detailed documentation

scr_setproperty_value.title: value / text Property

scr_setproperty_editable.title: editable Property
scr_setproperty_editable.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: editable ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: editable TYPE: boolean (true/false) APPLIES TO: TextField, TextArea, ComboBox DESCRIPTION: Controls whether the user can edit the content of an input control. When set to false, the control is read-only but remains visible and interactive (can be selected, scrolled). SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "editable", boolValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Make field read-only
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.idField", "editable", false);
  
  // Enable editing
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.nameField", "editable", true);
  
  // Conditional editing
  var isAdmin: bool = true;
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.salaryField", "editable", isAdmin);
  
  // Make ComboBox read-only
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.statusCombo", "editable", false);
DIFFERENCE FROM disabled: • editable=false: User cannot modify but can see and select text • disabled=true: Control is completely disabled, grayed out USE CASES: • Display-only fields that should not be edited • Conditional editing based on user permissions • Show calculated values that users can copy • Lock fields after form submission • Read-only mode for review screens

scr_setproperty_hgrow.title: hgrow Property
scr_setproperty_hgrow.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: hgrow ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: hgrow TYPE: string (ALWAYS, SOMETIMES, NEVER) APPLIES TO: All controls in HBox, GridPane layouts DESCRIPTION: Controls whether a control grows horizontally to fill available space in its container. Used for responsive layouts. VALUES: • ALWAYS - Control always grows to fill horizontal space • SOMETIMES - Control grows if space is available • NEVER - Control maintains its preferred width (default) SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "hgrow", growPriority);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Make field fill horizontal space
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.searchField", "hgrow", "ALWAYS");
  
  // Buttons don't grow
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.cancelBtn", "hgrow", "NEVER");
  
  // Allow growth if space available
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.titleField", "hgrow", "SOMETIMES");
  
  // Multiple fields sharing space
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.field1", "hgrow", "ALWAYS");
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.field2", "hgrow", "ALWAYS");
  // Both fields will share horizontal space equally
USE CASES: • Responsive forms that adapt to window size • Search fields that expand to fill space • Text areas that should use available width • Creating flexible layouts BEST PRACTICES: • Use ALWAYS for primary content areas • Use NEVER for buttons and fixed-size controls • Combine with prefWidth for hybrid sizing

scr_setproperty_vgrow.title: vgrow Property
scr_setproperty_vgrow.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: vgrow ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: vgrow TYPE: string (ALWAYS, SOMETIMES, NEVER) APPLIES TO: All controls in VBox, GridPane layouts DESCRIPTION: Controls whether a control grows vertically to fill available space in its container. Used for responsive layouts. VALUES: • ALWAYS - Control always grows to fill vertical space • SOMETIMES - Control grows if space is available • NEVER - Control maintains its preferred height (default) SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "vgrow", growPriority);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Make text area fill vertical space
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.contentArea", "vgrow", "ALWAYS");
  
  // Labels don't grow vertically
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.headerLabel", "vgrow", "NEVER");
  
  // Allow growth if space available
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.listView", "vgrow", "SOMETIMES");
  
  // Main content takes all vertical space
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.mainPanel", "vgrow", "ALWAYS");
USE CASES: • Text areas that should fill available height • List views and tables that expand vertically • Content panels that use all available space • Scrollable areas BEST PRACTICES: • Use ALWAYS for main content areas • Use NEVER for headers, footers, toolbars • Combine with prefHeight for hybrid sizing

scr_setproperty_margin.title: margin Property
scr_setproperty_margin.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: margin ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: margin TYPE: string (CSS-style spacing) APPLIES TO: All controls DESCRIPTION: Sets the external spacing around a control (space between the control and its neighbors). FORMAT: • Single value: "10" (all sides) • Two values: "10 20" (vertical horizontal) • Four values: "10 20 30 40" (top right bottom left) SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "margin", marginValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // 10 pixels on all sides
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.field", "margin", "10");
  
  // 10 pixels top/bottom, 20 pixels left/right
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.button", "margin", "10 20");
  
  // Individual sides: top right bottom left
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.panel", "margin", "10 15 10 15");
  
  // No margin
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.field", "margin", "0");
  
  // Large margin for spacing
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.section", "margin", "20 0 20 0");
USE CASES: • Create spacing between form fields • Add breathing room around buttons • Separate sections visually • Adjust layout spacing dynamically NOTE: Margin creates space OUTSIDE the control. Use 'padding' for space INSIDE the control.

scr_setproperty_padding.title: padding Property
scr_setproperty_padding.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: padding ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: padding TYPE: string (CSS-style spacing) APPLIES TO: All controls DESCRIPTION: Sets the internal spacing within a control (space between the control's border and its content). FORMAT: • Single value: "10" (all sides) • Two values: "10 20" (vertical horizontal) • Four values: "10 20 30 40" (top right bottom left) SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "padding", paddingValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // 8 pixels padding on all sides
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.textArea", "padding", "8");
  
  // 10 pixels top/bottom, 15 pixels left/right
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.panel", "padding", "10 15");
  
  // Individual sides: top right bottom left
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.container", "padding", "10 20 10 20");
  
  // No padding
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.field", "padding", "0");
  
  // More padding for readability
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.contentArea", "padding", "20");
USE CASES: • Add internal spacing to text areas • Create comfortable reading space • Adjust button text positioning • Control layout density NOTE: Padding creates space INSIDE the control. Use 'margin' for space OUTSIDE the control.

scr_setproperty_prefwidth.title: prefWidth Property

scr_setproperty_prefheight.title: prefHeight Property

scr_setproperty_minwidth.title: minWidth Property
scr_setproperty_minwidth.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: minWidth ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: minWidth TYPE: string or number (pixels) APPLIES TO: All controls DESCRIPTION: Sets the minimum width constraint. Control will never shrink below this width, even if container is smaller. SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "minWidth", widthValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Minimum width of 150 pixels
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.nameField", "minWidth", "150");
  
  // Ensure button is readable
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.submitBtn", "minWidth", "80");
  
  // Prevent field from becoming too narrow
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.searchField", "minWidth", "200");
USE CASES: • Ensure fields don't become too narrow • Maintain button readability • Prevent layout collapse • Responsive design constraints

scr_setproperty_minheight.title: minHeight Property
scr_setproperty_minheight.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: minHeight ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: minHeight TYPE: string or number (pixels) APPLIES TO: All controls DESCRIPTION: Sets the minimum height constraint. Control will never shrink below this height, even if container is smaller. SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "minHeight", heightValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Minimum height of 100 pixels
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.textArea", "minHeight", "100");
  
  // Ensure button is tall enough
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.actionBtn", "minHeight", "30");
USE CASES: • Ensure text areas have minimum size • Maintain button heights • Prevent layout collapse

scr_setproperty_maxwidth.title: maxWidth Property
scr_setproperty_maxwidth.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: maxWidth ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: maxWidth TYPE: string or number (pixels) APPLIES TO: All controls DESCRIPTION: Sets the maximum width constraint. Control will never grow larger than this width, even if container is larger. SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "maxWidth", widthValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Maximum width of 500 pixels
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.inputField", "maxWidth", "500");
  
  // Limit button width
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.cancelBtn", "maxWidth", "120");
USE CASES: • Prevent fields from becoming too wide • Maintain readable line lengths • Control maximum sizes in responsive layouts

scr_setproperty_maxheight.title: maxHeight Property
scr_setproperty_maxheight.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: maxHeight ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: maxHeight TYPE: string or number (pixels) APPLIES TO: All controls DESCRIPTION: Sets the maximum height constraint. Control will never grow larger than this height, even if container is larger. SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "maxHeight", heightValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Maximum height of 300 pixels
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.listView", "maxHeight", "300");
  
  // Limit text area height
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.notesArea", "maxHeight", "400");
USE CASES: • Prevent lists from taking too much space • Control text area maximum heights • Maintain layout proportions

scr_setproperty_alignment.title: alignment Property
scr_setproperty_alignment.content:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ scr.setProperty: alignment ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════ PROPERTY: alignment TYPE: string (lowercase) APPLIES TO: All controls DESCRIPTION: Sets how a control is aligned within its container cell. VALUES: • center - Center alignment • top_left, top_center, top_right • center_left, center_right • bottom_left, bottom_center, bottom_right • baseline_left, baseline_center, baseline_right SYNTAX: 
  call scr.setProperty(areaItem, "alignment", alignmentValue);
EXAMPLES: 
  // Center a label
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.titleLabel", "alignment", "center");
  
  // Right-align a field
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.priceField", "alignment", "center_right");
  
  // Top-left alignment
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.noteArea", "alignment", "top_left");
  
  // Bottom-center for buttons
  call scr.setProperty("myScreen.submitBtn", "alignment", "bottom_center");
USE CASES: • Center titles and headers • Right-align numeric fields • Position buttons in layouts • Fine-tune control placement

console_commands.short_description: Packages an EBS script into a binary .ebsp file
console_commands.long_help:
The '/package' command packages an EBS script into a binary .ebsp (EBS Package) file. This protects your source code by storing only the parsed Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) in a compressed, binary format. The original source code, comments, and formatting are not included in the package, making it difficult to view or modify the code.

Packaged scripts run identically to source scripts but load faster (no parsing required) and protect intellectual property. Import statements in packaged scripts automatically fallback to .ebsp files if .ebs files are not found, allowing you to distribute entire applications as packages.

Syntax: /package <input.ebs> [output.ebsp]

If output filename is not specified, it defaults to the input filename with .ebsp extension.
console_commands.documentation:
For complete documentation on packaging, see docs/PACKAGING_GUIDE.md

Key Features:
• Source code protection through binary serialization
• GZIP compression for compact file size
• Faster loading (pre-parsed AST)
• Seamless execution (works like .ebs files)
• Import support (automatically uses .ebsp if .ebs missing)

Example Workflow:
1. Create your script: myapp.ebs
2. Package it: /package myapp.ebs
3. Distribute myapp.ebsp (source code not visible)
4. Users run: java -cp target/classes com.eb.script.Run myapp.ebsp

Multi-File Applications:
For apps with imports:
1. Package main script: /package main.ebs
2. Package libraries: /package lib/utils.ebs
3. Distribute all .ebsp files
4. Imports work automatically

Security Note:
Packaging provides obfuscation, not encryption. It protects against casual viewing and simple reverse engineering, but determined individuals with Java knowledge could potentially reconstruct the logic. Suitable for commercial distribution but not for high-security applications requiring encryption.
